msItem.title: Letter to John Lane
msItem.author: Oscar Wilde
msItem.note: Autograph letter to John Lane, written from Worthing, discussing corrected proofs, publication details, pricing, United States copyright, and the production of several works, including The Woman of No Importance and The Portrait of Mr. W.H..

support.p: Autograph letter written in ink on paper, headed with printed “16, Tite Street, Chelsea S.W.” and handwritten “5 Esplanade, Worthing”.

layout.p: Single column; line breaks preserved in this transcription.

handNote.p: Modern pencil annotation in another hand on page 6.

additions.note: Pencil annotation “RO-O-O” at top of page 6 (not Wilde’s hand).

origin.p: Written at Worthing in August 1894, and addressed to John Lane, Wilde’s publisher at The Bodley Head.

bibl.title: Lady Windermere’s Fan
bibl.author: Oscar Wilde
bibl.note: Wilde’s first major society comedy, set in fashionable London drawing rooms and exploring jealousy, scandal, and maternal sacrifice. In the letter, Wilde cites this play as a typographical model for how the U.S. copyright notice should be printed in the edition of The Woman of No Importance.

bibl.title: The Woman of No Importance
bibl.author: Oscar Wilde
bibl.note: A society comedy exposing double standards in Victorian morality through the fate of Mrs. Arbuthnot, a “fallen woman” confronting the aristocrat who ruined her. Wilde discusses here its simultaneous copyright in America and the timing of the book’s publication to coincide with the provincial tour of the play.

bibl.title: The Portrait of Mr. W.H.
bibl.author: Oscar Wilde
bibl.note: A hybrid tale combining literary criticism and fictional forgery, built on the idea that Shakespeare’s Sonnets were inspired by a boy-actor named Willie Hughes. In the letter, Wilde suggests that Elkin Mathews might publish a new edition of the work, with altered print run and price.

bibl.title: Oscariana
bibl.author: Oscar Wilde
bibl.note: Oscariana is a privately printed collection of Oscar Wilde’s epigrams and witty aphorisms, compiled by his wife Constance Wilde during their stay in Worthing in the summer of 1894. The anthology was entrusted to the publisher and bookseller Arthur L. Humphreys, who issued it in a small private edition in 1895. The collection highlights Wilde’s characteristic paradoxes, social satire, and conversational brilliance.

projectDesc.p: This TEI file is part of a corpus of three letters by Oscar Wilde encoded for the course “Modelling Humanities Data with TEI-XML” at the École nationale des chartes.

state.p: Author, playwright, journalist, and essayist associated with the Aesthetic and Decadent movements.

person.note: In the early 1890s, Oscar Wilde was at the height of his literary career, publishing a series of successful society comedies with John Lane at The Bodley Head. This letter reflects Wilde’s close involvement in the material and commercial aspects of publication, including proof correction, pricing, and arrangements for American copyright.

state.p: London publisher and co-founder of The Bodley Head.

person.note: John Lane (1854–1925) was a British publisher who, together with Elkin Mathews, founded The Bodley Head, an important London publishing house associated with fin-de-siècle literature and the Yellow Book circle. Lane published several of Wilde’s works, including his society plays, and played a central role in shaping the presentation and marketing of Wilde’s books.

state.p: London publisher and early partner in The Bodley Head.

person.note: Elkin Mathews (1851–1921) was an independent London publisher and an early partner of John Lane at The Bodley Head. In this letter Wilde envisages Mathews as a potential publisher for The Portrait of Mr. W.H., suggesting different print runs and pricing for a revised edition.

state.p: Artist, book designer, and close collaborator of Oscar Wilde.

person.note: Charles Ricketts (1866–1931) was a British artist, illustrator, and book designer who collaborated closely with Oscar Wilde on the visual presentation of his works. Ricketts designed bindings and layouts for several of Wilde’s books, and in this letter Wilde refers to Ricketts’ views on the format, print run, and price of The Portrait of Mr. W.H..

state.p: Writer, translator, and women’s rights advocate.
Wife of Oscar Wilde (married in 1884); mother of Cyril and Vyvyan Wilde.

person.note: Constance Mary Lloyd (1859–1898), later Constance Wilde, was an Irish writer and activist involved in dress reform and women's rights. She married Oscar Wilde in 1884 and played a significant role in shaping his early literary and public life. In the summer of 1894, while living in Worthing, she compiled a selection of Wilde’s epigrams and aphorisms, later privately printed as Oscariana. After Wilde’s trial and imprisonment in 1895, Constance changed her surname and that of her children to “Holland.” She died in 1898 following spinal surgery.

state.p: Publisher, bibliophile, and manager at Hatchards, London.
Published Constance Wilde’s private anthology Oscariana in 1895.

person.note: Arthur Lee Humphreys (1865–1946) was a prominent London bookseller and publisher, long associated with Hatchards bookshop on Piccadilly. Known for his bibliophilic refinement, he oversaw limited and private editions for distinguished authors. In 1895 he privately printed Oscariana, the anthology of epigrams compiled by Constance Wilde, contributing to the preservation of Oscar Wilde’s reputation during a difficult period.

state.p: London publishing house active in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.

org.note: The Bodley Head was a London publishing firm founded by John Lane and Elkin Mathews. It became closely associated with avant-garde and fin-de-siècle writers, including Oscar Wilde, and was known for the distinctive design and high production values of its books.

place.note: Worthing is a seaside town in West Sussex, England. Wilde stayed there in the summer of 1894, during which he named one of his principal characters “Jack Worthing” in The Importance of Being Earnest. This letter was written from Worthing, from the address “5 Esplanade”.

16, Tite Street, Chelsea, in London, was Oscar Wilde’s primary London residence in the early 1890s. The printed letterhead of this address appears at the head of the letter, though the body of the letter was written from Worthing.

Liverpool is a port city in northwest England. Wilde notes in this letter that The Woman of No Importance had been lectured on there and used as a topic for sermons, and that the play should therefore have a good sale in the city.

New York is mentioned in connection with arrangements for American copyright. Wilde explains that he is sending proofs of The Woman of No Importance to New York so that copyright can be secured in the United States before publication.

correspAction.note: Publisher at The Bodley Head, London.

div.p:
I return
corrected proofs —
the title page,
dedication, play-bill
etc. have not yet
come — please
send them. I
will not
require any
more proofs of
the play, but I
wish that the
reader
w[oul]d. would go
through the play
once and correct
any slips in the
use of “will”
and “shall” —
my use of the
words is Celtic
not Saxon.

With regard
to future arrangements
I think the plays
better remain with
Mr. Lane — at
The Bodley Head — as
they form a series
that should not
be broken —
Mr. Mathews might
have “ The Portrait
of Mr. W.H. ” — and
this
w[oul]d. would give an
opportunity of
making some alterations
in the issue and
price — 300 or 250 —
and 50 large paper
w[oul]d would be better. Also
the book
sh[oul]d. should be a
guinea. These, at
least, are
Mr. Ricketts' views.
This book should be
out by end of
October.

I have to get
The Woman of No
Importance copyrighted
simultaneously in
America (please
mark copyright
as in Lady Windermere:
this is most
important) — and
am sending proofs
to New York. I
think the book can
be out by Sept. 15.
when the play goes
on tour. I shall
tell my American
agent to wire
to me as soon as
copyright is
secured, so as to
have no delay.

The play
sh[oul]d should
have a good sale
at Liverpool —
where it has been
lectured on, and
formed a text
for reckless
sermons.

I have to thank
you for allowing
my wife to make
selections of phrases
for her anthology.
